Situation1: They interact warmly with a long line of shoppers during a busy lunch hour.
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: New safety steps were highlighted during the last briefing and everyone was asked to apply them consistently.
Story: The lunch rush at the store always brings a wave of chatter and hurried footsteps. As a cashier, I’m expected to greet every customer with a smile, keep the line moving, and make each person feel welcome. Today, the line snakes past the bakery, and I can sense the impatience growing. I try to keep my tone light, asking about people’s days, scanning items quickly, and double-checking prices. But in the back of my mind, I can’t shake the volunteer coordinator’s words from this morning’s briefing: “Everyone must follow the new safety steps—no exceptions.” I volunteered to help at the register today, and the new guidelines mean I should sanitize the counter and keypad after every customer, even if it slows things down. The customers are watching, some tapping their feet, others glancing at their watches. I feel the pressure to keep them happy, but I also know the coordinator will check if we’re following the rules. My hands hover over the sanitizer bottle, my heart pounding as I wrestle with what to do next.
